message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of polydactyly, cleft palate, micrognathia, and clenched fists suggests Edward syndrome, which is caused by nondisjunction of chromosomes. In utero infections and errors in metabolism do not lead to this specific genetic syndrome, and autosomal dominant genes do not cause such severe intellectual disability and physical features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a diagnosis of Trisomy 13 (also known as Patau syndrome). This genetic syndrome occurs due to nondisjunction of chromosomes, where there is an extra copy of chromosome 13.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased nuchal translucency and abnormal levels of alpha-fetoprotein, β-hCG, and pregnancy-associated plasma protein suggest a genetic syndrome. The physical features described are consistent with trisomy 13, which is caused by nondisjunction of chromosomes, specifically an extra copy of chromosome 13. In utero infections and errors in metabolism do not typically result in such a genetic syndrome, and trisomy 13 is not caused by an autosomal dominant gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased nuchal translucency and abnormal quadruple screening suggest a genetic condition. The physical features described are consistent with Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome, which is caused by nondisjunction of chromosome 18 during meiosis. This results in three copies of chromosome 18 instead of the usual two copies. This condition is not caused by in utero infections, errors in metabolism or autosomal dominant genes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased nuchal translucency and the confirmatory test results indicate signs of Down syndrome, which is caused by nondisjunction of chromosomes. In utero infections and errors in metabolism do not present with these physical features, and autosomal dominant genes usually do not result in a severe intellectual disability.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased nuchal translucency, abnormal alpha-fetoprotein levels, and decreased β-hCG and pregnancy-associated plasma protein suggest a chromosomal abnormality, specifically a nondisjunction of chromosomes. The physical features and poor prognosis also suggest Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), which is caused by an extra copy of chromosome 18. In utero infections and errors in metabolism may cause developmental abnormalities, but they do not typically present with the specific symptoms described in this case. Autosomal dominant genes to not typically result in severe intellectual disability or physical malformations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased nuchal translucency and abnormal screening test suggest aneuploidy, which is a result of nondisjunction of chromosomes. The physical features described match those of Trisomy 13, which is caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 13. The other options are not common causes of Trisomy 13.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest the genetic syndrome is Trisomy 13, which is caused by nondisjunction of chromosomes, specifically having an extra copy of chromosome 13. In utero infections and errors in metabolism do not cause this type of genetic syndrome. Autosomal dominant genes would require only one copy of the gene to be affected, but Trisomy 13 requires an extra copy of a whole chromosome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described are characteristic of Edward’s Syndrome, which is caused by the nondisjunction of chromosomes during cell division, leading to an extra copy of chromosome 18. This results in severe intellectual disability, as well as physical abnormalities. In utero infections or errors in metabolism do not typically cause genetic syndromes. Autosomal dominant genes are inherited from one parent and do not typically result in these types of physical and developmental abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest an increased risk of having a baby with Trisomy 18, which is caused by nondisjunction of chromosomes. This means that there is an error in the separation of chromosomes during cell division, resulting in an extra copy of chromosome 18.
